title: Global change: global threats
abstractText:
A half-day workshop for circa 60 lower sixth students at Swansea University 12 March will explore how scientific understanding of global change and natural hazards can contribute to public debate in deciding how to allocate resources to protect society in the future.

An introductory briefing session will provide an overview of the science behind environmental hazards that threaten society today and initiate a discussion on how the risks from those hazards may be affected by global changes such as global warming and population pressures. In small groups, students will investigate one hazard through guided internet and library searches, with the aim of preparing arguments to justify allocating public resources for further study of that particular hazard. These arguments will be presented before the full assembly as a poster and an oral presentation. The full assembly will vote on which hazard is most deserving of public resources and further scientific effort.

Prizes will be awarded for the team producing the best poster and for the team presenting the most successful argument. Group topics will be chosen from wildfires, volcanic eruptions, sea-level change, meteorites, cyclones, flooding and demographic pressures that increase vulnerability to natural disasters
